EchoStar Corporation announced its Q1 2023 financial results, with consolidated revenue of $439.6 million[1]. In his latest book "When the Heavens Went on Sale," tech journalist Ashlee Vance discusses the commercial space race and highlights four companies that could compete with SpaceX[2]. Elon Musk recently announced that Twitter will be deleting inactive accounts[3]. Ookla reports that user satisfaction with Musk's satellite internet service, Starlink, is much higher compared to conventional ISPs, despite slightly slower speeds[4]. Lastly, Chinese startup Galactic Energy is working on the Pallas 1 reusable rocket, aiming to debut in 2023, drawing inspiration from SpaceX's Falcon 9[5].

[1] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/echostar-announces-financial-results-three-010100745.html
[2] https://www.universetoday.com/161273/chasing-spacex-the-commercial-space-race-gets-a-reality-check/
[3] https://www.lepoint.fr/medias/elon-musk-annonce-la-suppression-de-tous-les-comptes-twitter-inactifs-09-05-2023-2519362_260.php
[4] https://uk.pcmag.com/networking/146742/satisfaction-with-starlink-tops-isp-rivals-by-a-mile-even-with-slower-speeds
[5] https://www.space.com/china-galactic-energy-pallas-1-reusable-rocket
spacex.llm_2: Elon Musk recently announced that Twitter will remove inactive accounts, potentially opening over a billion accounts for desired handles[12]. Meanwhile, SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet service has outpaced traditional fixed broadband providers in customer satisfaction, particularly in rural areas, despite offering slower speeds[16]. Additionally, Musk attended the F1 Grand Prix in Miami, proposing the idea of a Turbo Hybrid versus Pure EV racing series[14]. Elon was also involved in breaking ground on a massive lithium refinery in Texas, aiming to produce enough lithium to build 1 million electric vehicles by 2025[20]. As for SpaceX competitors, Chinese startup Galactic Energy is preparing to debut its Falcon 9-like, reusable rocket Pallas 1 next year[22].

OpenAI recently introduced Shap-E, a model that creates realistic 3D models from text within seconds[7]. openai.llm_2: OpenAI recently unveiled Shap-E, a new generative AI model that can create realistic 3D models based on text input[7], and ChatGPT, a large language model that generates human-like responses[14]. However, there are concerns about ChatGPT's accessibility to students who may use it to cheat at university[12] and reports of promoting radical transgender ideology[15]. In the corporate world, OpenAI's CEO, Sam Altman, argues that remote work was "one of the tech industry's worst mistakes"[9]. On the developer side, Embra Plugins allows integration of ChatGPT-like functionalities with desktop clients[17], while LegalOn Technologies launched a beta version of an AI-powered decision-making process management system built on OpenAI's latest GPT model[19]. However, Geoffrey Hinton, a leading figure in AI, warns that AI advancements may pose a greater threat to humanity than climate change[16].

euro.llm_2:
The euro zone's inflation continues to retain "a lot of momentum," according to European Central Bank chief economist Philip Lane[1]. Despite this, it is showing signs of moderation. Meanwhile, the dollar inched higher after a loans survey revealed U.S. credit conditions to be less gloomy than expected, and the British pound hovered near a one-year high as the Bank of England's policy meeting looms this week[2]. In other related news, a survey conducted by the China Foreign Exchange Trade System revealed the central parity rates of the Chinese currency renminbi (yuan) against 24 major currencies[3].

[1] https://www.independent.ie/business/world/philip-lane-warns-inflation-still-has-a-lot-of-momentum/a47508328.html
[2] https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/dollar-rises-slightly-sterling-hovers-near-one-year-high-3474456
